newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: ABSA CUTS TO CUT FIXED HOME LOAN RATES.
newsitem.headline: ABSA CUTS TO CUT FIXED HOME LOAN RATES.

text.p: Amalgamated Banks of South Africa Ltd (Absa) said on Tuesday it would cut its fixed interest rates for residential mortgage loans in excess of 100,000 rand from July 1.

Over a 12-month period the rate would drop from 19 percent to 18.20 percent while over a 24-month period, the rate would ease from 18.50 to 18.25 percent, Absa's mortgage loans general manager Richard Gahagan said in a statement.
The banking group also said a new 18-month fixed rate term period would be introduced with a mortgage rate of 17.60 percent -- 2.4 perecent lower than the prevailing home loan base rate.
It said the decision to reduce the rates had been taken in the light of Absa forseeing a reduction in interest rates in the short to medium term.
"The introduction of these lower fixed rates will appeal to those home owners who are concerned that interest rates may rise and therefore wish to fix their monthly mortgage payment," Gahagan added.
Absa's move follow on the footsteps of Standard Bank which also announced a cut in its fixed and capped home loan rates last Friday.
